Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Canarias, good. We have received new orders to escort a merchant convoy. There have been many attacks in the area and Command expects more trouble.
Escort duty. A waste of time, Capitán. We will not defeat the Morganas by allowing them to attack as they please. We must seize the initiative.
Perhaps, but we must defend international trade or our support will crumble and the fleet will not receive the men and supplies needed to carry on the fight.
The merchants would be safer if the Brujas del Mar were too busy running from us to be able to threaten them, Capitán.

Fields.MenuText: I would rather be hunting as well, but even if we could find the Morganas, they have superior endurance at sea. We would simply be chasing them without result.
The oceans are vast, and the Morganas can disappear in their fog. We have to fight defensively.
Trust me, there is nothing I dislike more than an escort mission, but orders are orders. We are protecting the merchants.

Fields.DialogueText: They would not be able to run from me forever, Capitán.
A solely defensive war is one that is already lost, Capitán.
Por supuesto, Capitán. Duty must come first, but we must make Command understand proper strategy moving forward.
I'm afraid this war is not like any other. The Morganas have no supply lines, no leadership, no logistics of any kind. They only grow stronger as they fight, while we grow weaker.
You must not despair, Capitán. We shall defeat them yet.
I'm not despairing. But we must face facts if we are to develop a winning strategy.
I am confident you will find a way, Capitán. Until then, let us carry out our orders.
@BATTLE
Have we received new orders, Capitán? I am growing weary of escorting convoys.
And this from the warship that calls herself a sheepdog. We are still tasked with protecting local shipping. I'll let you know if that changes.
Forgive me, Capitán. I am more inclined to play the role of a knight seeking a dragon than a simple guard protecting merchant carts.
If I recall correctly, Spain's most famous knightly order was charged with keeping the roads safe for pilgrims and travellers. Not a bad legacy to continue.
The Order of Santiago? True, Capitán, but they were not a sedentary order. They weren't content to patrol roads. They were on the front lines during the Reconquista.
The knights knew their countrymen would not be safe until Spain was forever free of invaders, and so they joined the crusade to drive the Moors out of Iberia once and for all.
Now we are in a similar crusade against the Morganas. Is that what you're saying?
Sí, Capitán. We are modern caballeros fighting against an unholy enemy.

Fields.MenuText: The Moors weren't "unholy" by any means. The Reconquista was an unfortunate clash between two cultures that couldn't see each other as anything but adversaries.
If we are modern knights, then we still have a duty to the people who depend on us... even if our mission isn't as glorious as being on the frontlines.
Next you're going to have me tilting at windmills.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, I am not so certain of that. Either way, the enemies we face now are not human, and there should be no shame in our victory.
Hmph. De acuerdo, Capitán. However, if I see a dragon, do not expect me to be satisfied allowing it to roam free.
I am not sure I appreciate the comparison, Capitán. If you are Don Quixote, that would make me Sancho Panza, and I am not a farmer.
A fair point. Well, we had better get back to our escort duties.
It seems our enemies have come to us. Morganas on the horizon.
We have to intercept them before they can reach the convoy. Ready to slay some dragons?
Heh. Ready to charge them down, Capitán.
@BATTLE
Enemy ships in the area, Capitán. Ready to engage.
@BATTLE
Good work everyone. We have forced their retreat.
Sí, Capitán. We continue to dominate the battlefield, and yet these Brujas del Mar continue to seek us out. It is as if they do not understand their own defeat.
A tactical defeat, yes. But not a strategic one. Our enemy only seems to get stronger no matter how many times we defeat them.
They still cannot match our strength, Capitán. We will see them banished from our waters yet. We need only teach them fear.
I'd like to hit them where it hurts, but we don't understand the Morganas well enough to do that yet.
My cannons might create a blaze to consume one of the Morganas, if only they were not so quick to skulk away. Let them watch one of their sisters burn, and they will know fear.

Fields.MenuText: Making an example of one of these Morganas is just what we need.
That's a little bloodthirsty, Canarias. There other ways to dishearten an enemy without such brutality.
Perhaps, but there is no guarantee that one Morgana cares about another's fate.

Fields.DialogueText: An effective tactic, Capitán. Destroy your enemy's will to fight, and you win the war.
Nothing motivates quite like fear of death, Capitán. Especially a painful death.
Hmph. I suppose so, but is worth trying all the same.
So you believe these Morganas can feel pain?
I can only tell you that Belles do, Capitán.
Is there something on your mind, Capitán?
You mentioned Belles feel pain. Could you elaborate on that? You feel pain when the ship is struck, of course.
Sí, Capitán. That is one sort of pain I experience. But there are others as well.
Others?
When my actions cause the death of crewmates, when you make me understand I have failed in my duty, when I think of my lost sister… at these times, I feel pain.

Fields.MenuText: That makes sense. I guess I'm still learning the extent to which you are tied to the ship.
I hope that is not all you feel.
I'm sorry for asking. Sometimes it's easy to forget you aren't a human.

Fields.DialogueText: I am the ship, Capitán. I feel the waves against my bow, the stir of my turbines, everything. But I am more as well. I feel things a machine never could.
No, Capitán. I also feel the thrill of victory, the peace of the open waves, the joy of companionship. All of these things.
I think I will take that as a compliment, Capitán.
Do you think the Morganas feel the same way you do?
I am not sure, but I do not think so. They are strange foes, their minds seem... broken. If they do feel, it is not in any way in which I could easily relate.
I wonder if this whole war could have been avoided if we just understood our enemy better.
Unlikely, Capitán, but it seems we have another opportunity to learn more about our enemy. A Morgana has been sighted heading in our direction.
Make ready for combat.
@BATTLE
Capitán, we have received a new communication from the Command.
We still haven't cleared out all the Morganas in this area. Have more been spotted?
No, Capitán. The Spanish government has requested a special envoy be brought on board to observe us in action.
An envoy?
Señor Ciro Rosales Garcia. I am afraid I am not familiar with him.

Fields.MenuText: We have enough problems with the Morganas, and I don't want to be babysitting some Spanish politician.
The Spanish government wants someone to spy on us, eh? Sounds like trouble.
Well, you are a Spanish ship. We will have to do our best to make this Mr. Rosales comfortable.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitán! I am surprised by you. After all your talk of duty, I would have thought you understood your duty to Spain as well.
I am a warship of España, Capitán. If they wished to know anything, they would only need to ask.
I am glad you are agreeable to this, Capitán. I am looking forward to having a Spanish gentleman on board.
Fine. When should we expect him?
Not for some time still, Capitán. You need not worry, I will make all the necessary arrangements.
In that case, what do you say we get back to the hunt?
Absolutamente, Capitán.
@BATTLE
Fog spotted ahead. All crew to battle stations.
Capitán! It is a feint! Enemies to our starboard!
@BATTLE
Ah, Canarias, you are practicing your timple. I never did get a chance to compliment you on your last performance.
Not practicing, Capitán. This piece is called "Chacona." It is supposed to be played leisurely. I doubt it would serve well for a concert, but I find it meditative.
I'm glad you can find time to relax between battles. It's just as important for the mind to rest as it is for the body... er, or hull.
I am not tired, Capitán... I am... angry.
Angry? Why? You fought well today.
It is my sister, Baleares. I often find myself thinking of her after a battle. If she were alive today, perhaps she too would be a Belle.
Why would missing your sister make you angry?
Because she sank, Capitán! She allowed herself to be destroyed by the enemy when she was the greatest warship in the Spanish fleet. When she was the flagship... she failed.

Fields.MenuText: Baleares sank under enemy fire. I don't think that counts as "allowing herself to be destroyed."
Baleares was destroyed serving her country. That's not failure. That's sacrifice.
I don't think you're angry at Baleares, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: She could have survived, she could have won! But instead she sank and failed her country, failed me!
¡¿Sacrificia?! No, Capitán, there was no need for her sink that night. She had no excuse.
You are wrong, Capitán. Baleares had no right to fail, no right to sink.
Canarias, I don't think you are angry. I think you are afraid.
Afraid of what, Capitán? She is already gone.
Failure.
Morganas sighted off the port bow!
@BATTLE
All right, now, let's get back on course.
Capitán, I have been thinking about what you told me, and... may I talk to you about Baleares?
Oh course, Canarias. We have some privacy at the moment.
Whenever you're ready, Canarias.
It happened in the dead of night. Our squadron was tasked with escorting Italian transports when, by chance, we came upon a Republican force.
After a brief exchange, we broke contact. Our admiral wanted to wait until morning when our superior firepower could be brought to bear, but the Republicans had other plans.
They changed course to follow us. We spotted their cruisers and began firing, but we didn't see their destroyers until it was too late.
Baleares was in front of me when she was struck. I had to turn hard just to avoid hitting her sinking stern...
That was the last time I saw her.

Fields.MenuText: There was nothing you could have done. You shouldn't blame yourself, or your sister.
I'm sorry, Canarias.
You ran away?

Fields.DialogueText: I realize now that I wasn't angry. I was afraid. When I saw Baleares destroyed in front of me, I realized I could have easily been in her place.
In that moment, I felt betrayed, I suppose that makes me an awful sister.
This was before I had a voice, Capitán. Our capitán couldn't risk waiting to pick up survivors with enemy ships still in the area. And I can't say I blame him.
In war, things happen which are simply beyond our control. You have to accept that and allow yourself to forgive.
After the civil war, when I awakened, I knew I could never allow what happened to Baleares to happen to me. Now, perhaps I am ready to accept that this is not something I can control.
Forgiving yourself doesn't mean forgetting her. Cultures across the world have ways of remembering those they have lost. We could always raise a drink in honor of Baleares.
I'd like that.
To my sister, lost before she had the chance to awaken. May she find rest knowing I continue the fight for both of us. Vaya con Dios, mi hermana.
Well said, Canarias. I'm sure she would have been one heck of a Belle. To Baleares.
We were supposed to be the invincible…
But she let me down.
Oh, excuse me, Captain. I didn't see you there.
What's the rush?
It's Canarias. She wants to make sure everything is shipshape before Mr. Rosales arrives.
Ah yes, the Spanish dignitary. We will rendezvous with him soon. It seems Canarias is looking to make a good first impression.
You can say that again. She's got half the crew working round the clock!
You there! Stop dawdling and get those work details passed out! I want my deck polished, my cannons cleaned, my signal flags washed, and...
Oh, hello, Capitán! I did not see you.

Fields.MenuText: You're giving a lot of orders, Canarias. Don't you think I should have some say in my crew's activities?
No problem, Canarias. It seems you have your work cut out for you.
I hope Mr. Rosales will appreciate all the trouble you're putting my crew through.

Fields.DialogueText: These are all routine tasks, Capitán. They shouldn't require your attention, or mine for that matter.
I must look my best, Capitán. I am the flagship of the Spanish fleet. It would not do for my countrymen to see me at anything less than my best.
I hope you do not think I am pushing the crew too hard, Capitán. I am not asking them to do anything outside their normal duties.
Just make sure the crew gets some rest now and then. They will need to look their best for our dignitary as well.
Captain, we have a mist forming in the area.
If those Brujas del Mar so much as scratch my paint, I will chase them down and turn their hull into a floating scrapyard!
*Ahem* Well then, I suppose we had best get to battle stations.
@BATTLE
Captain, we are nearing the rendezvous point.
Morganas! Approaching fast.
Take them out before they intercept the transport.
@BATTLE
Well, now that that's over, we had best welcome our new dignitary aboard.
No! I am still in tatters. This is no proper way for a Dama del Mar to receive a government official.
I can't be helped. If this Mr. Rosales is a perceptive man, he will recognize the marks of a fighting ship.
I hope you are right, Capitán. There he is.
Capitán, I presume? I am Ciro Rosales Garcia of the Falange National Party. Permission to board?
Granted, Mr. Rosales. Welcome aboard the Canarias. I speak on behalf of the Protection Force when I say she has done her country proud.
Señor Rosales, I am very pleased to make your acquaintance. You must forgive the poor shape of my hull. I am afraid the Morganas do not allow us much respite.
Ah... it talks. How clever. Capitán, I have much business to discuss and little time for distraction. Would you mind if we spoke alone?

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised at your manners. I had thought a Spanish gentleman as yourself would be more gallant toward his hostess.
Anything you have to discuss with me may be discussed with Canarias present.
Little time for distraction or civility, it seems. Very well, excuse us, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: Hostess? Ah, you mean the Belle. Very well, if it pleases you to continue the farce, Capitán. It is delightful to meet you, Canarias. Now, please, excuse us.
I would prefer to wait to give the Belle orders until we have discussed the orders, Capitán. I would not wish for it to become confused.
Civility? I am not a man of flowery introductions, Capitán. Or did you mean toward the Belle? What use has a warship for civility?
I, um... I... please, excuse me, Capitán.
I believe you've managed to insult your own flagship, Mr. Rosales. Now I'm afraid I must attend to repairs before we speak. The Morganas may strike again soon.
Are you all right, Canarias? You have been quiet since Mr. Rosales came aboard.
I am fine, Capitán. I appreciate your concern, but it is unnecessary.
I must admit, I wouldn't have expected you to be so... patient with our ill-mannered dignitary.
Some choice words certainly came to mind, but Mr. Rosales is here on behalf of España, and as such, I will give him the respect due his position, even if he is not respectful of me.

Fields.MenuText: I admire your self-control, Canarias. You put your duty ahead of your personal pride.
Mr. Rosales may represent Spain, but so do you. His actions reflect poorly on his own country.
How unfortunate. I would have liked to hear you argue with someone else for a change.

Fields.DialogueText: Gracias, Capitán. I believe I have you to thank for a few lessons in putting duty before pride. Still, it is not easy to bite one's tongue.
That is no consolation to me, Capitán. I am happy to suffer insult for the sake of España, but pointing out Señor Rosales' shortcomings will only make matters worse.
Careful, Capitán. If you are looking to start a fight between myself and Señor Rosales, I promise I will drag you into the middle.
Fair enough. In the meantime I want you to know you are a Dueña de la Nave worthy of respect. Both myself and the crew know it, and if Mr. Rosales doesn't, that is his failing.
Heh. Gracias, Capitán. Now, I think I would like to blast something with my cannons. Do you think we might do a little hunting?
Let's get underway.
@BATTLE
Capitán, we must speak.
Mr. Rosales, forgive me, my duties have kept me quite busy.
Please, call me Ciro, Capitán. I believe we got off to a bad start. I would prefer we have a cooperative working relationship.
It's not me you upset, Mr. Rosales. If you are looking to make amends, you should start with Canarias.
The Belle? It is upset with me? Don't tell me the warship throws temper tantrums.
I think you have some misconceptions about what a Belle is, Mr. Rosales. First off, you should really refer to "it" as "she". And yes, she is upset with you.
I am here to work with you, Capitán. Not to apologize to a machine's manifestation. You are familiar with the reason the Spanish government sent me here, yes?

Fields.MenuText: You are here to observe Canarias in action against the Morganas. At least, that is what the Protection Force was told.
You're supposed to be an observer. So far, it seems you have taken it upon yourself to be an antagonist to Canarias.
Your orders don't concern me as much as your behavior. If you wish to remain aboard my ship, you will apologize to Canarias and treat her with respect.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, but one's official orders and the reality of one's task are often quite different. I am not here to observe the Morganas so much as I am here to observe you, Capitán.
If you wish to label me as an antagonist, Capitán, it would be best you understand that I am here because of your actions, not hers.
Very well, Capitán. I will apologize to this Belle if it is that important to you. However, you should really be more concerned with the impression you make on me.
Is that a threat?
It is my mission, Capitán. Our reports indicate that Canarias has taken considerable damage while under your command.
We face a powerful foe, Mr. Rosales. Injury is inevitable.
It should be clear to all that Belles are the future of naval warfare, Capitán. Spain does not wish to lose her most prized warship in a war that is not her own.
Does Spain intend to rescind their loan of the Canarias to the Protection Force?
That, Capitán, depends on my observations.
Excuse me, Captain. We have Morganas on the horizon.
Make sure Canarias gets to the bridge. This conversation is not over, Mr. Rosales.
Indeed.
@BATTLE
We have received reports of Morganas in the area, Capitán. Permission to alter course?
Let's clear them out.
@BATTLE
Well fought, Capitán. It is quite something to see the power of these Morganas firsthand, and equally impressive to witness their defeat.
Thank you, Mr. Rosales. However, I believe you have some unfinished business with Canarias. I would prefer you address it before attempting more flattery.
Indeed. *Ahem*
Canarias, I wish to express my sincere apologies. I was improperly briefed as to the nature of Belles. Seeing you in combat has expelled those illusions.
I accept your apology, Señor. Please let us say nothing more on the matter. My only wish is to be seen as a true servant to España.
But there is much more to say. I came here under the assumption that you were the manifest expression of a machine. Now, I understand that you are more than that.

Fields.MenuText: Canarias is a fine warship and a brave soldier.
There are still many things we don't understand about Belles, but Canarias is no machine.
Glad you finally figured that out, Mr. Rosales.

Fields.DialogueText: I studied your specifications at length before I arrived, Canarias. But is seems I still need to get to know you. Would you care to have dinner with me?
I studied your specifications at length before I arrived, Canarias. But is seems I still need to get to know you. Would you care to have dinner with me?
I studied your specifications at length before I arrived, Canarias. But is seems I still need to get to know you. Would you care to have dinner with me?
Excellent. Until later, then.
I shall, Señor Rosales, but as a soldier I will need to be repaired and ready for combat first.
I will be happy to attend, Señor. But please understand you dine with a lady, not a weapon.
A charming suggestion, Señor Rosales. I would be delighted to accept your polite invitation.
I'm glad things are patched up between you and Mr. Rosales.
Sí, Capitán. He has been much more respectful of late. He has even taken to sending me little gifts.
Well, he is a politician. I'm sure he knows how to turn on the charm once he knows he has to be diplomatic.
He tells me he is descended from a line of Spanish capitanes. His ancestor fought at the battle of Trafalgar.
Then I suppose he is lucky his ancestor survived. That was not a good day for Spain.
I wish I had been alive in those times, Capitán. When ships stretched their arms to the wind, and the fortune of nations was decided by a broadside.

Fields.MenuText: It is a romanticized era, steeped in nostalgia. I'm sure reality wasn't so poetic.
You mean to tell me you would trade your steel hull for a wooden one, or your turrets for a gun deck?
Ah, the age of sail, the true genesis of naval power. A pity it is gone.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! So dour, Capitán. There is nothing wrong with a little poetry, or longing for days past.
I suppose not, Capitán. Still, there is something magical about the thought of being propelled by a full sail and wooden rudder.
Yes, and with it, Spain's dominance of the seas. Still, perhaps it will come again.
Maybe. It looks like we have company, more Morganas no doubt.
Excuse me, Captain. We have reports of…
Morganas in the area?
Uh, yes, Captain.
Very well. Time to get back to the present day, Canarias.
Sí, Capitán. The wind favors us.
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitán. I was hoping to talk to you. I was reviewing your mission reports, and I am a little confused by one of your entries. You mention that Canarias fired without orders.
She was anticipating my orders. The miscommunication was resolved.
And later you state Canarias moved under her power to engage the Morgana battleship, Sabotage.
She did. However the issue has been dealt with. Canarias has proven exceedingly cooperative during our most recent battles.
The Spanish government was under the impression these Belles only acted upon the orders of their capitanes. However, these reports indicate a level of... initiative.
What is your question, Mr. Rosales?
Can this ship disobey your orders, Capitán?

Fields.MenuText: She certainly can be stubborn at times, but Canarias is loyal, Mr. Rosales.
Canarias chose me as her captain, Mr. Rosales. She continues to obey my orders because she chooses to.
Perhaps. It hasn't really come up.

Fields.DialogueText: That was not the question, Capitán. Men and women may be loyal, but a warship is a machine.
She "chooses" to follow orders. So, it is possible she may "choose" not to as well.
You don't think this question bears immediate interrogation?
Canarias is more than a warship, Mr. Rosales. She is a Belle. She has a mind of her own, but I assure you her heart is in the right place.
Capitán, we have spotted a Morgana pack not far from here.
Oh! Mr. Rosales, were you two discussing something?
Nothing of importance, my Dueña de la Nave. I'll let you get to your work. Excuse me, Capitán.
@BATTLE
Capitán, I wonder if I might ask you a hypothetical question.
About Canarias?
About warfare. You, perhaps more than anyone else, have had a great deal of exposure to Belles. How would you believe they would react to combat with another Belle?
A "hypothetical" battle between two Belles? Well, in my experience each Belle is unique. Perhaps it would be more enlightening to ask Canarias.
Would you care to weigh in, my dear?
I think you would find me more than equal to any adversary, Señor Rosales. However, I must ask why you are curious about such a specific scenario.
Once this war with the Morganas is over, the next war will be fought between Belles. It is only prudent to consider such warfare before it occurs.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not so sure a war fought between Belles is so inevitable, Mr. Rosales.
We have already asked a great deal from the Belles in the fight against the Morganas. I could not bear the thought of having them fight each other.
Fighting a war with an eye to the next... There are too many unanswered questions about the nature of Belles to be able to draw concrete conclusions at this time.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitán, I doubt the Belles will have much choice when the time comes, provided, of course, they continue in their duties to their country.
True, Capitán. However I doubt the Belles will have much choice when the time comes, provided of course they continue in their duties to their country.
True, Capitán. However I doubt the Belles will have much choice when the time comes, provided of course they continue in their duties to their country.
Excellent, Canarias, I am pleased to hear you say so.
We need to focus on fighting today's war, not tomorrow's. Let's get underway, Canarias, I'm sure there are Morganas nearby.
Sí, Capitán.
@BATTLE
We were created as warships, I believe war is in our nature.
I appreciate your concern, Capitán, but I will not shrink from my duty to my country for any reason.
If a time comes when Belle must fight Belle, I will answer the call of my country.
Hello, Canarias. Are you playing a song you wrote? I'm unfamiliar with that piece.
Oh no, Capitán. This is "Concierto de Aranjuez" by Joaquín Rodrigo, although I am flattered you think I wrote it.
I was thinking about what Mr. Rosales had mentioned, about what happens after the war is over. Would you consider becoming a professional musician?
That is generous of you to suggest, but I do not think that would be practical. It is not as though I could sit in a concert hall.
Well, you have a whole deck of space available. Perhaps even more if some of the turrets were removed. Granted, it would be unique stage, but that just adds to the charm.
Remove my turrets? No, Capitán, that would never do for a warship.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps, once the war is over, you wouldn't need to be a warship anymore. You could become whatever you wanted.
Heh, true enough. I don't think I could picture you without cannons.
You never chose to join the military. It's not right for you to be forced to stay in the navy for the rest of your life.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps...to be honest, I have never thought of that before. I have always been a warship. I just assumed I always would be.
I can't imagine! The idea of being unable blast my enemies into oblivion seems... unsettling.
Humans join the military, Capitán. I am a Belle and was born to it. I have never thought of leaving the navy, and do not know if I ever would.
Perhaps you should just give the matter some thought. You are a conscious creature, and as such, you should have a say in your future.
I will, Capitán. In the meantime, I believe we have some fog forming up ahead. Your warship stands ready.
Let's do it.
@BATTLE
So much paperwork to do, so little time...
Ah, I didn't see you there, Canarias.  Come in, I was working on some reports.
Capitán, I am curious. What do you think you will do after the war?

Fields.MenuText: I've had enough of fighting. I think I will find somewhere quiet to settle down.
I can't imagine leaving the navy.
I haven't really thought about it.

Fields.DialogueText: I have already seen much of the world, but I think I would like to continue to travel for a time. There is still much more to see.
I have already seen much of the world, but I think I would like to continue to travel for a time. There is still much more to see.
I have already seen much of the world, but I think I would like to continue to travel for a time. There is still much more to see.
Thank you, Canarias. Now then, we have new coordinates from the fleet. Possible Morgana activity.
¡Excelente! Heh, the sooner we tear apart these obstructions, the sooner we may end this war and find our future.
@BATTLE
Before the Morganas came, people would go on pleasure cruises all over the world for just the same reason.
A pleasure cruise...that would be nice.
Does that mean you have thought about leaving the military after the war?
I did think on what you said, and I do not believe I could ever bring myself to leave the navy. But thank you for allowing me to see there are alternatives.
Well, if that is your choice, then so be it. I suppose during peacetime, warships still travel around the world.
I hope that when you retire, you will come and visit me occasionally. I think I would miss you.
Before the Morganas came, people would go on pleasure cruises all over the world for just the same reason.
A pleasure cruise...that would be nice.
Does that mean you have thought about leaving the military after the war?
I did think on what you said, and I do not believe I could ever bring myself to leave the navy. But thank you for allowing me to see there are alternatives.
Well, if that is your choice, then so be it. I suppose during peacetime, warships still travel around the world.
Hopefully, once all this is over, we can continue to serve together. I cannot imagine anyone else as my capitán.
Before the Morganas came, people would go on pleasure cruises all over the world for just the same reason.
A pleasure cruise...that would be nice.
Does that mean you have thought about leaving the military after the war?
I did think on what you said, and I do not believe I could ever bring myself to leave the navy. But thank you for allowing me to see there are alternatives.
Well, if that is your choice, then so be it. I suppose during peacetime, warships still travel around the world.
Well, whatever your future brings, I hope you will stay in touch, Capitán. I have come to value our conversations.
Would you tell me, my dear, what do you think of the command of the Capitán?
The Capitán is a true leader, Señor. One I would be happy to follow anywhere.
That is a wonderful sentiment, my dear. And yet, have you considered what you would do if the Capitán ordered you to attack a Spanish ship?
That would never happen, Señor! The Capitán would never ask me to commit such treason.
Of course, but the Capitán is loyal to the Protection Force, not the Spanish Fleet. It is not impossible to consider the two may someday be at odds.
I have lived through one civil war already, Señor Rosales. I would not seek to start another. My loyalty is to España and to the Protection Force.
Don't you see how that is a divided loyalty?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure she does, Mr. Rosales. Just as I'm sure she is aware that division is a greater enemy to us than even the Morganas.
Well, Ciro, it seems I have caught my "observer" looking to instigate mutiny.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Capitán, it is not division I seek, but understanding. I must know if Canarias' duty is to her capitán or to Spain. Recent history should make my motives clear.
Eavesdropping, Capitán? Any "mutiny" on this ship would have to be against the interests of Spain, and I am nothing if not a servant to my country.
The Capitán may be a good commander, Canarias, but humans are prone to all manner of infighting and changing allegiances. You must be aware of your loyalties before they are tested.
Please, Señor. I have absolute faith in my capitán, just as I have faith in my country. Do not ask me to lose faith in either, for that would prove disastrous for us all.
Sorry to interrupt, but our scout planes report a Morgana not far from here.
Thank you. Canarias, plot a course. Mr. Rosales, I'm afraid I will have to ask you to leave the bridge while we are in combat.
Very well, Capitán, if that is your wish.
@BATTLE
Capitán, we have an S.O.S. from a Soviet submarine. She is under attack by Morgana destroyers.
Send our response. We're on our way.
@BATTLE
Our enemies flee, Capitán.
Radio the Soviets, see if they need any further assistance.
Capitán, it seems the battle is over. May I have a word?
I am very busy, Mr. Rosales. Can it wait?
I will be brief, Capitán. I must protest Canarias being used to fight alongside Soviet ships.
You know the Protection Force is international, Mr. Rosales. We will fight alongside ships from any nation under Morgana attack.
I understand that, Capitán. But you have other ships at your disposal. It would be more appropriate if they were used.
The Spanish government knew Canarias would be fighting alongside Soviet ships. Why this sudden protest?
That was before we understood the "independent" nature of these Belles. It sends an improper message to our people to have our warship cooperating with communists.

Fields.MenuText: Let's be clear, Mr. Rosales. You are onboard as an observer, and only in that capacity. You have no right to either question my commands or make any commands of your own.
I think it sends the perfect message. It tells the people of Spain the only way we will defeat the Morganas is with international cooperation. It tells them the truth.
Look, Ciro, if I have to listen to anymore of your nonsense I'm going to confine you to quarters, dignitary or no.

Fields.DialogueText: It is you who should be clear, Capitán. Canarias was given to the Protection Force to fight Morganas, not to further any anti-government agenda.
Who are you to decide what is the truth? You have no right to use Canarias as political pawn.
Be careful who you threaten, Capitán. I may only be an observer, but I am well connected. Any actions you take against me will have consequences.
Mr. Rosales, my loyalty is to España. I fight alongside ships of other nations to advance her interests.
It is not your place to decide what is in Spain's best interest, Canarias. Right now, I fear you are being used to send a subversive message to your countrymen.
There is no subversion here, Mr. Rosales. We are at war with an enemy that will require international cooperation if we wish to have a hope of defeating them.
Please listen to the capitán, Señor Rosales. Our fleet must have unity to achieve victory.
I see. You'll have to excuse me, Capitán. It seems I have a disappointing report to make to my government.
Capitán, do you really think España might remove me from your command?
I'm not sure. Mr. Rosales certainly seems to dislike me.
Yet even he admits that you are a capable commander. I do not understand why I should be removed from your command.
Well, I guess it comes down to what you believe, Canarias.
What I believe?
Rosales is concerned about the impact my way of thinking is having on you, on your ideology. He doesn't want me to turn you against Franco and the Falange party.
But that is ridiculous. I would never turn against General Franco.

Fields.MenuText: It's the perception. If you appear to be cooperating with forces who are actively opposed to Franco's rule, people might begin to think you are opposed as well.
You're more than a warship, Canarias, you're a symbol. As such, Rosales can't afford to have you associated with anyone who isn't loyal to the Falange party.
What if I asked you to? Rosales can't afford to take that risk.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't understand. I have to cooperate with our allies, even if I disagree with them. You taught me that, Capitán. It is not a lesson I can unlearn.
I understand that I am a symbol, but I must also be a symbol of victory. Otherwise, what hope do the people have? To that end, I must remain associated with you, Capitán.
He can't afford not to. If Señor Rosales thinks that España can survive without the Protection Force, he does not understand naval warfare.
Well said, but it's not me who needs convincing.
Then I shall organize a dinner for the three of us. We must come to an understanding before Señor Rosales causes irreparable damage.
That's a good idea, but it will have to wait. It seems a mist is starting to form.
@BATTLE
A fine dinner, Canarias, my compliments to the chef.
Just wait for dessert, Señor. We are having banana splits.
I'm afraid you will have to excuse me, Canarias. I have work I must complete before tomorrow.
I had hoped you might stay a little longer, Señor Rosales. I had hoped you and the Capitán might make amends.
Yes, I gathered as much from the private dinner and stilted conversation. Tell me, Canarias, was this your idea or an idea of the Capitán?
It was mine.
Canarias feels, as I do, that she is doing the most good for her country by fighting the Morganas as part of the Protection Force. We had hoped to convince you of the same.
I'm afraid it is going to take more than a banana split to do that.
Please, Señor. A country which does not control the waves can never be a world power. If we allow the Morganas to triumph, Spain will forever be in their shadow.
That does not concern me, Canarias. We can no longer afford to have you indoctrinated by subversive elements. You must return to Spain until we find an appropriate capitán for you.
Indoctrinated?

Fields.MenuText: I have never suggested anything that could be construed as subversive, Mr. Rosales. This paranoia is counterproductive to your own interests.
We may have our disagreements, Mr. Rosales, but you have no right to try and control what Canarias thinks or is exposed to.
Nonsense. Either you have some hidden agenda, or you are trying to separate an effective combat team for some petty perceived slight.

Fields.DialogueText: Your objections are irrelevant and misguided, Capitán. The mere fact that Canarias suggested this dinner is evidence enough that you are having a negative influence.
Your objections are irrelevant and misguided, Capitán. The mere fact that Canarias suggested this dinner is evidence enough that you are having a negative influence.
Your objections are irrelevant and misguided, Capitán. The mere fact that Canarias suggested this dinner is evidence enough that you are having a negative influence.
I think I've heard enough.
So have I. You are a discredit to your government, Mr. Rosales. Now, if you'll excuse us, Canarias and I have a war to fight, until such time as you sabotage those efforts.
Come, Capitán. I need to find something to destroy.
@BATTLE
I only put together this meeting to prevent you from taking actions that will harm the interests of España, Señor.
Exactly. You think you know better than a member of the Falange party what is best for Spain. That attitude would be dangerous in the mind of any soldier, and even more so in a Belle.
I have had enough of this. You are not paranoid, Señor Rosales. You are a fool.
I only put together this meeting to prevent you from taking actions that will harm the interests of España, Señor.
Exactly. You think you know better than a member of the Falange party what is best for Spain. That attitude would be dangerous in the mind of any soldier, and even more so in a Belle.
So you are trying to control my every thought. I am a Dueña del Mar, not a slave, Señor Rosales.
I only put together this meeting to prevent you from taking actions that will harm the interests of España, Señor.
Exactly. You think you know better than a member of the Falange party what is best for Spain. That attitude would be dangerous in the mind of any soldier, and even more so in a Belle.
Is that what this is about? All you are doing is proving that you do not know what is best for España. A new capitán will not change that.
Captain, I am receiving a Morgana radio signal. I think it's Sabotage.
These Morganas must be gluttons for punishment. Well, I'll be happy to supply more.
Hold it right there, Capitán! Don't tell me you intend to endanger Canarias by sending her against a Morgana battleship!
We've beaten her before, Señor Rosales. Besides, fighting Morganas is my duty.
You stay out of this, Canarias.

Fields.MenuText: Your cowardice is not welcome on my bridge, Ciro.
No, you stay out of this, Ciro. Canarias and I have work to do, and you are in the way.
Risk is part of war, Mr. Rosales, but I assure you it is Sabotage that should be afraid, not you.

Fields.DialogueText: How dare you! Canarias, you must choose now. Will you remain loyal to your country, or will you obey this idiot capitán of yours!?
How dare you! Canarias, you must choose now. Will you remain loyal to your country, or will you obey this idiot capitán of yours!?
How dare you! Canarias, you must choose now. Will you remain loyal to your country, or will you obey this idiot capitán of yours!?
You said it. Take us forward, Canarias. I want to give our old friend a warm reception.
I am coming, Sabotage. Did you miss me?
@BATTLE
As always, I am loyal to España and my capitán. Your objections will not keep me from either duty.
Excuse me, Mr. Rosales, I'm afraid I must ask you to leave the bridge.
For once I am glad to hear from Sabotage. I am looking forward to smashing her hull apart.
As always, I am loyal to España and my capitán. Your objections will not keep me from either duty.
Excuse me, Mr. Rosales, I'm afraid I must ask you to leave the bridge.
Once we have dealt with Sabotage, perhaps we can throw Ciro overboard and be rid of all our problems.
As always, I am loyal to España and my capitán. Your objections will not keep me from either duty.
Excuse me, Mr. Rosales, I'm afraid I must ask you to leave the bridge.
He does not understand what to be afraid of. He should fear me.
More Morganas to starboard!
@BATTLE
Canarias! I've had it with your insubordination! You will turn this ship around and head for the nearest Spanish port!
Am I to understand you are explicitly instructing me to disobey my orders, Señor Rosales?
You are a warship of Spain. As an official of Spain, you will obey me. Is that understood?
I think I understand completely.
Capitán! Señor Rosales has conspired to stage a mutiny. I recommend you have him arrested immediately.
That won't be necessary, Canarias. Mr. Rosales is leaving aboard the next transport we come across, regardless of destination.
Well, Ciro, it looks like you'll be spending the rest of your time with us in the brig.
Mutiny, Mr. Rosales? That is a serious charge. I believe I will have to contact your government about that.
This is preposterous!
You won't get away with this. I have powerful friends. You will pay dearly for this offense!
Goodbye, Ciro. The pleasure has been all yours.
Come along now, little man. Time to put you in your place.
The only thing preposterous here is a little imbécil who has long overstayed his welcome, who thinks he has the right to order me around.
I think I'll let you deal with this situation as you see fit, Canarias.
You had better hope a transport comes by soon, Señor Rosales. Otherwise, you will find yourself swimming home.
This is preposterous!
The only thing preposterous here is a little imbécil who has long overstayed his welcome, who thinks he has the right to order me around.
I think I'll let you deal with this situation as you see fit, Canarias.
This is preposterous!
The only thing preposterous here is a little imbécil who has long overstayed his welcome, who thinks he has the right to order me around.
I think I'll let you deal with this situation as you see fit, Canarias.
It is too bad we do not have stocks. I suppose the brig will have to do, but first we will have to interrogate you to ensure there are no other conspirators.
I think we can skip the trial this time, Capitán. He has admitted his guilt clearly enough. Perhaps the crew can fashion a plank for the mutineer.
Señor Rosales has disembarked, Capitán.
And not a moment too soon.
I must admit, this is not how I imagined sending off a Spanish dignitary.
Do you regret kicking him off?
I only regret that we were not rid of him sooner. I must ask though, Capitán, why do you think the two of you got along so poorly?

Fields.MenuText: He saw you as a weapon to be controlled. I see you as a comrade.
He's a politician. His kind have no place aboard a warship on the front lines.
He tried to drive a wedge between us for the sake of a flimsy nationalist agenda.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitán. Not just for the way you see me, but for the many times you have helped me see that I am more than just a warship.
I think it was more than just that, Capitán. You are one of the most patient people I know. It took a great deal to push you to anger.
He tried to force me to choose between you and España. He failed.
So what do you think, Canarias? What if I did order you to betray your country?
If you were ever foolish enough order that, Capitán, than I would be happy to know I had a worthy new adversary.
However, I know you would never ask that of me. Because I know you respect me, Capitán.
I do.
We have new orders from Command. There are Morganas threatening a nearby shipping lane.
Well, let's get to it before Spain decides to remove you from my command.
Sí, Capitán.
@BATTLE
This time, I know I have never heard that song before.
Cierto, Capitán. You inspired me to compose my own music.
Really? Does it have a name?
It is called "Por Baleares."

Fields.MenuText: It's beautiful.

Fields.DialogueText: I wanted to thank you once more, Capitán. You have never faltered in your support, no matter the extent of my personal demons or the nature of our enemy.
You have always stood by my side, and I am proud to have you as my capitán, and as my friend.
Thank you, Canarias. I hope we are able to continue to fight side by side.
Oh, I would not worry too much, Capitán. We just received a message from Spain. They rejected Señor Rosales' recommendations.
Really?
It turns out someone else with a great deal of influence in España wrote another report which contradicted much of Señor Rosales' findings.
Wait, how did you... when did…
Can't a Belle keep a few secrets from her capitán?
Heh. Well done, Canarias. I am glad to have you as a Belle, and as a friend.
You may, Capitán. Now, it seems we have some Morganas to take care of. Shall we?
Yes, we shall.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It suits her. I'm sure she'd be pleased.
You've been carrying that inspiration for a while.

Fields.DialogueText: True, but she wasn't the only thing that has inspired me lately.
You really think so?
I think so, too.
